Key Point

Orthogonality Relation

For any integers \(m\), \(n\), including the case \(m = n\), \[ \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi } \sin nt \cos mt \hspace{0.15cm} dt = 0 \]

We shall use this result shortly but need a few more integrals first.

Consider next \[ \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi} \cos nt \cos mt \hspace{0.15cm} dt \] where \(m\) and \(n\) are integers.

Using another trigonometric identity we have, for the case \( n \neq m \), \[ \begin{align} \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi} \cos nt \cos mt \hspace{0.15cm} dt &= \dfrac{1}{2} \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi} \left\{ \cos(n+m)t + \cos(n - m)t \right\}dt \\ &= \dfrac{1}{2} \left\{ 0 + 0 \right\} = 0 \end{align} \] For the case \(n = m\) we must get a non-zero answer since \(\cos^2 nt\) is non-negative. In this case: \[ \begin{align} \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi} \cos^2 nt \hspace{0.15cm} dt &= \dfrac{1}{2} \displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi} ( 1 + \cos 2nt ) dt \\ &= \dfrac{1}{2} \Big[ t + \dfrac{1}{2n} \sin 2nt \Big]_{-\pi}^\pi = \pi \hspace{1cm} \text{provided n} \neq 0 \end{align} \] For the case \(n = m = 0\) we have \[\displaystyle{ \int _{-\pi}^\pi} \cos nt \cos mt \hspace{0.15cm} dt = 2\pi\]
